segments.text: Side 3 equipment section continued.
The following sections of organizing are called 44, radar on lower end, the radio on lower end, radar, IFF, RCM, sonar, functional components.

Each of these sections initiated procurement requests using one, allowance list established by installation and maintenance, two, equipment characteristics set up by C&O, three, data on number of shifts to be equipped, four, training school manuals, land lease directives, and so on.
The stock maintenance section was also organized to handle items common to all of these sections, insulators, cables, headphones, and switches.
In the fall of 1944, an audit group was set up, proposed by a number of officers from business fields.
This group reviewed controls, accurate requirements, and so forth, and it all instituted 119 cancellations of equipment worth a total of $70 million between December 1944 and March 1945.
In October 1944, Unified Requirements Determining Procedure was set up to eliminate duplicate requirements and guesswork.
Under this Procedure, one requirements card was established for each type of equipment or each item to be procured by the Radio Division.
The system of allowance of battle damage continues to occasion unbalanced production.
However, the use of flat percentage was not abolished immediately.
For example, it was used exclusively for sonar up to 1945, but it was still used in May 1945 for new types of equipment for which no experience existed.
Page 281, this is.
Page 283.
Bureau of Ships, Electronics Design Division, procured electronics equipment for itself and the Bureau of Aeronautics, as well as the Marine Corps and the Maritime Commission of the Vietnamese.
Procured for these agencies in line with the Navy policy of centering all procurement of the largest use of the given type.
I'm not going to discuss the details.

Page 284, the Bureau of Ships prepared detailed specifications in consultation with the Bureau of Aeronautics, negotiated the price, directed production effort, and approved all commitments affecting design and production.
The Bureau of Ships also initiated the design and development of new electronics equipment, the Bureau of Aeronautics paying the direct cost.
And it says that if the business did not procure from the Bureau of Autonomous, it would have provided that Bureau with technical advice.
Altogether, however, the division procured about nine-tenths of the Navy's electronics requirements.
This system gave one bureau an overall view of the situation with respect to production, price, component, and labor, while eliminating duplication of many functions.
The disadvantage was the delay in processing procurements through several technical bureaus.
Inseparate authority and responsibility in continually obscuring the status of procurement in the two bureaus.
Practice, however, of having Burea designate the contract to reduce defectiveness of provided procurement for the chief advantage of having bureauships handle Burea procurements.
or that the former could then consider from an overall point of view factors such as keeping contractors in business, comparative pricing, labor situation, and so forth.

Theoretically, the function of selecting the contractor, negotiating price, and awarding the contract belonged to Buce Santa, which before the war performed this function for the use of procurement other than electronics.

Though electronics have the technical complexity and rapid technical development, the huge acceleration of procurements placed a job beyond the technical competence of the Bureau of Suppliers and Accounts.

Authorities for initiating procurement requests in the electronics division came from CNO 1, either in correspondence setting up ship or shore allowances and requesting specific equipment, or 2, in requests for equipment for claimant ships and so forth, resulting from CNO directives.
Before July 44, procurement requests were prepared by specialist sections of the installation and maintenance branch.
Procurement requests after that were prepared by the cognizant equipment section, radar, and so forth.

It's interesting, on page 288, the lack of pricing experience, the need for speed, the problem for rapid changes, and specifications were dealt with by using acceptance of the negotiations up to July 1944.
Either letters of intent or contracts specifying maximum price with later redetermination down but only.
The letter of intent described all known specifications in the name of ceiling price and so forth.
In July 1944, there were nearly 500 letters of intent outstanding to the value of nearly a billion dollars and 300 maximum price contracts.
Parenthetically, I don't believe this applied to RMD, but on page 289 it says, cost plus fixed fee contracts were rarely used.
Manufacturers opposed them, and the Navy cost inspection service was not large enough.
This is King Cooper speaking.
I think that they did use cost plus fixed fee on some of the receipts.
Another interesting comment on 290.
The dearth of firms with experience in facilities made it necessary during 1942 and 43 to rely almost entirely on the very large firms.
Thus, the production report lists only 44 prime contractors in November 1942, and the largest 14 firms of which held 92% of the dollar volume.
On page 311, after describing how they had to change from sending equipment to a specific ship, which might be some equipment that stayed long time in storage,
On 3-11, the bombardment continues.
It was decided, therefore, to create so-called pools of electronic apparatus in all naval districts requiring radio, radar, and sonar materials.
These pools were set up in early 1943, 1942 for radar, under cognizance of the radio material officer by the industrial manager.
Materials were shipped to the pools under requirements set up by the RMO.
The material was not marked for specific vessels except in special cases.
The RMO was to allocate the stocks according to his own judgment, keeping in mind the need for balance in new construction and maintenance needs.
The placing in pools and Navy yards and Navy supply depots made the electronic equipment available for the first ship arriving on the period, which added precedence high enough to claim that.
For example, a DD would have precedence over a YP.
On the other hand, this system had the defect that each claimant regarded the entire pool as his own,
For example, the Naval Supply Depot at Mechanicsburg had large stocks of TCS's placed there for various claimants.
Section 6 claimants shipped against it and the stock ran out quickly.

This kind of situation was met in the summer of 1943 by C&O setting up precedence categories in place of the pool system for equipment for various classes of ships and for various other uses, Marine Corps, amphibious, advanced base, and so forth.
The pool was divided into four categories, new construction controlled by Bureau of Ships, maintenance ships controlled by Forces of the Flood,
Shore station is controlled by Bureau of Ships.
Advanced base is controlled by SIGPAC and SIGPAC jointly.
Later, the fifth category was set up consisting of material removed from shipment stations.
This category was given to the Bureau of Ships for reassignment in category 1 to 4.

In order to apply this category system, the radio division thereupon organized the assignment section, which uses CNO directors as a guide in assigning the total estimated production of each type of the various claimant sections.
I'm trying here to get the information that set up Tommy Austin,
Tommy Rogers, under which I worked at Pearl.

Page 313, the establishment of the pool system also made it necessary, at least desirable, to assign a special personnel to the yards with the technical knowledge to receive, issue, and store electronics apparatus.

In almost complexity of electronics apparatus and parts, there were 5,000 types of capacitor, an equal number of resistor types, and 2,000 glasses of vacuum tubes, made it impossible for ordinary naval storekeepers and suppliers to handle radio equipment.
The supply officer for radio was accordingly set up to help the radio material officer, RMO, with the technical aspects of installation and maintenance.
Page 314.
The principal pools were located along the central and west coast of the Navy Yard and other Navy establishments where material could be located or installed aboard vessels.
In addition, radio pools were located at principal and advanced bases such as Pearl Harbor and the Nile Zone and Guam.
Several factors had complicated the problem of establishing completely adequate pools.

There had always been shortages of certain special types of critical materials, and this shortage was accentuated by the rapid technical development that made types obsolete often before the time they were produced.
In addition, the fleet and the standard of war moved frequently and rapidly.
By the time bases like Nubia and New Guinea had been built, a fleet operation had descended 1,000 miles north.
A major movement from east to west coast of continental pools was called for by the collapse of Germany and the concentration of the war in the Pacific.
Difficulties with actually getting, installing, and maintaining equipment was enormous.
Page 320.
Approximately 3,000
Approximately 3,000 naval vessels of all types and sizes were completely equipped with delicate and expensive radio communication equipment during the last year of the war.

Thinking of Red Bacon and the other engineers, the story of the field engineering services and the installation and maintenance branch for the period of June 40 to June 1945 was the story of expansion and extension to meet the needs of the Navy.
In June of 1940, there was no field engineering service.
In October 1941, the first field engineering service contract was led.
It proved so successful that contracts had been led to cover most electronic equipment.
By June 1945, there were approximately 1,000 factory field engineers, and it totaled a cost of over $1 million per month.
The anti-submarine warfare engineers reached a zenith of 65 engineers in November 1944.
This group tapered off toward elimination on 1 June 1945, its function being taken over by the Navy.
The Electronic Fuel Services Group consisted of 250 engineers in August 1945.
This is an indication of how the printing went up.
In 1940, there was one periodical, the Radio and Sound Bulletin, issued from the radio division.
By 1945, the publication section issued seven periodicals, published 50 books, and each month approved 64 equipment instruction books and supervised distribution of 80,000 copies.
On page 327 is a chart of such radio program, chart 24, 29, which is dramatic in its growth.
That ends this particular description, Bureau of Ships World War II, volume 4.
And we go into Crossroads, beginning on page 329.

Less than a year after the devastation of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the eyes and ears of the world turned toward a little atoll in the middle of the Pacific Ocean to discover just how cataclysmic this explosion of splitting atoms could be.
While the results of the two atomic bomb tests conducted at the Bikini Atoll on 1 July and 25 July 1946 are still not firmly

Fully determined, while much of the information remains of a classified nature, it is possible to discuss in general terms this operation's crossroads in which the Bureau of Ships played such an important role.
Detail account of this incredible operation, which is contained in Joint Task Force One.
I'll repeat that.
Since the historical report, Atomic Bomb Timothy,
Abel and Baker Operations Crossroads of Director of Ship Material, Joint Task Force One, contains a complete detailed account of this incredible operation.
This study will confine itself to unclassified excerpts of that report and to general comments which may serve to unify the parts.

On 20 June 1945, when the European War was ended and the Pacific War was approaching its climactic phase, Vice Admiral E.L. Cochrane, Chief of the Bureau of Ships and Vice Admiral, then Rear Admiral G.F. Hussey, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance,

addressed a joint letter to the Chief of Naval Operations proposing a comprehensive program for testing high explosives against merchant and warship hawks, captured enemy vessels and United States Navy combatant ships about to be stricken from the active list.
It was decided to go beyond the model studies and full-scale caisson tests, which were normally carried out by the two bureaus.
This proposal for, quote, controlled destructive testing and a planned program to elicit fundamental information on damage to ship-like structures by high explosives, end quote, met with approval.
The two bureaus and their research agencies sped up the planning, which has already been done to carry out this program.
Meanwhile, other forces were at work.

In the New Mexico desert near Almagordo on 16 July 1945, scientists of the Manhattan District secretly carried out the Trinity Test with the first explosion of the atomic bomb, which has been under civilian and military development since July of 1939, when Einstein and other scientists brought the military potentialities of such a weapon to the attention of President Roosevelt.
On 5 August, only three weeks after this test, the first military atomic bomb exploded over Hiroshima.
And a few days later, another atomic bomb exploded over Nagasaki, hastening the Pacific War to its close.
The Japanese, faced with this new terror as well as imminent,
invasion surrendered unconditionally on 14 August, nine days after the first atomic bomb had been dropped.

Even before technical personnel made their studies in Japan, reports of damage at Hiroshima and Nagasaki offered conclusive proof, if any were needed, of the tremendous military potentialities of this new weapon.

On 28 August, the Chief of Bureau of Ships, Vice Admiral Cochrane, informed his design and research agencies, which were planning new programs of underwater explosion work with conventional explosives, that the Bureau of Ships, quote, must be prepared to undertake broad-scale experiments with the atomic bomb.

On 1 October, Vice Admiral Cochrane and Vice Admiral Hussey sent another letter to the Chief of Naval Operations stating that the repairments of the atomic bomb had made it imperative that a program of full-scale testing be undertaken.
to determine the effects of this type of bomb, both underwater, above water, and against ships of various types.
This is on page 332.
It continued that the two bureaus would prepare and present for consideration of the earliest practical data testing program.
In a letter,
On 16 October, Admiral E.J.
King, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet and the Chief of Naval Operations, recommended the Joint Chiefs of Staff approve a test of the atomic bomb against naval vessels.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff undertook the study of this proposal.

The Bureau of Ships was represented on this subcommittee of planners, a joint staff planners were appointed, and a planning subcommittee under the chairmanship of Major General Curtis LeMay, Army Air Force.
The Bureau of Ships was represented on this subcommittee by Captain Alec Niskan, K-N-I-S-K-E-R, and head of the design branch.
The Secretaries of War and of the Navy made the first public announcement of the proposed test, and a joint press release on 10 December is on page 333.
stating that the Army and Navy contemplated a, quote, joint test of atomic bombs against naval vessels, end quote.
On 10 January 1946, the President approved the recommendation of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
And on 11 January, the Joint Chiefs of Staff created Joint Task Force One, appointing Vice Admiral W.H.P.
Blandy, the Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Special Weapons, as his commander.
Admiral Blanding had already begun specific planning for the two tests, starting with consideration of various proposals for target arrays drawn up by the Bureau of Ships.
Page 334.

The mission of Joint Task Force One was publicly announced by its commander on 24 January, when Vice Admiral Blanding told the Senate Committee of Atomic Energy, the mission of Joint Task Force One is primarily to determine the effects of the atomic bomb upon naval vessels in order to gain information of value to the national defense.
The ultimate results of the test, so far as the Navy is concerned, will be their translations into terms of United States sea power.

Secondary purposes are to afford training of the Army Air Force's personnel in attack with the atomic bomb against ships and to determine the effect of the atomic bomb upon military installations and equipment."
He also announced that the atomic bomb tests had been assigned the code name Operation Crossroads.
Now on page 335, some exploratory discussions and organizations were set up.
As the Bureau of Ships had a permanent interest in Operation Crossroads, Admiral Cochrane recognized his great responsibility, which were devolved upon the officers elected to represent the Bureau.
Accordingly, he decided to appoint Rear Admiral T.A.
Sahlberg, head of the research branch of the Bureau of Ships, as a senior member of a large bureau group for Operation Crossroads.
Admiral Sahlberg had been a deputy member of the Tolman Committee appointed by Major General Leslie R. Groves in the fall of 1944, almost a year before the Trinity test, and so forth.
This committee under the chairmanship of Tolman had studied many suggestions.
On 17 January, Admiral Cochrane appointed Admiral Solberg to this position because it was desirable to have someone in his rank and experience coordinate all the varied ones.
An order dated 22 January set up Code 180, the Crossroads Section, and on the same day, Admiral Solberg was designated as head of the section and Captain Niskanen as his senior assistant.
Meanwhile, Admiral Sahlberg and Captain Niskan consulted with Rear Admiral then Commodore W.S.
Parsons as to the relationship of Admiral Sahlberg's group to the rest of the task force.

In the first organization chart prepared by the task force, Admiral Parsons was shown as Deputy Task Force Commander for Technical Direction, and under him was the Technical Director, Dr. R.A. Sawyer, S-A-W-Y-E-R, in charge of scientific aspects of the tests, particularly the preparation of the bombs and instrumentation to measure their effects.
and so on, and Admiral Sahlberg received this overall technical responsibility as, quote, director of ship material assigned under Admiral Parsons.

It was agreed that all instrumentation would be subject to the technical director's approval, that's Dr. Sawyer, but that the director of ship material, this is Admiral Sahlberg, would have a major interest in problems involved in locations of instruments on target ships and in their installation as well as the results they gave
with reference to ship damage.
It was therefore agreed that the closest liaison between the technical director and the director of ship material would be necessary.
It goes on to further describe the organization.

The heavy involvement of the Bureau of Ships, which went beyond the target ships themselves to include special interests in electronics, oceanography, ship's instrumentation, and explosion phenomena, made the task of the director of ship material diverse and complex.

On the one hand, Admiral Solberg was responsible for all the Bureau of Ships' activities and operations crossroads, including special projects like oceanographic instrumentation, which was to be provided for the most part in the water rather than on the target ships themselves.

On the other hand, he was responsible for all target ships, as well as for all materials and installations on those ships, and for close liaison with the technical director on all instrumentation problems affecting the target ships.
Of interest, opposite page 338 is chart 30, showing the director of ship material, 014, with Admiral Sauberius, 014.
Of interest are the oceanography group, which is under Dr. Sawyer, 013, the oceanography group, 013B, and the ship's instrumentation group, 013C, and the electronics group, 013D.
quite an interesting chart.
The Bureau of Ships Group was quite an important group.

The first concern was that whole machinery and electrical gear of almost 90 target ships plus reserve ships ranging from landing craft to carriers and battleships be placed in proper material condition.
It goes on to talk about indoctrination of crews, electrical power, and so forth, and says the 139 target

must be equipped not only to transport personnel and supplies, but to provide laboratory space for scientific groups in the study of oceanographic, radiological, and other phenomena, and to provide facilities for press and radio, as well as manned surveillance and observers.
That's on page 344.
Then after describing the preparation of the target ships, on page 349,

is a list of the actual target vessels, which included the Arkansas, the Pennsylvania, the Salt Lake City, the two jet vessels, Nagato, Sakawa, and the German Prinz Eugen, the dear old Saratago, and the Independence, the famous old Lampson destroyer, the Skipjack, the Sea Raven, the Tuna, and the Skate.
Many, many well-known wartime two ships.
Stop.
Page 354 gives a full page from A through Y of a check-off list of what had to be done to prepare one of the target ships.
On page 355, the preparation of the 139 target vessels assigned to the task force required conversion or modification
necessary to provide adequate accommodations for more than the normal complement of most of these ships.
Office space and equipment were essential for the administration work to be carried on, and various technical groups required laboratories and other scientific facilities.
Most of the work in conveying these vessels offered no difficulty, apart from the fact that very little time was available.
Additional communication facilities required for operations and public relations were provided.

after showing how the organization went on to teams to enter the harbor after the thing for inspection now the after the fact on 360 it says on 15 16 june the directorship material had rehearsals for initial boarding teams which were realistic in every detail the army air forces had also been conducting independent drill with bombing runs on nevada

On 24 June, Queen Day, a full-dress rehearsal was held on the exact conditions of the actual Crossroads operations, except that a 500-pound phosphorus bomb, a fragmentation bomb, was substituted for the eagerly-awaited atomic bomb.
Weather forecasts on 30 June indicated that the day selected for Able Day, the 1 July, would be satisfactory.
And at 9 o'clock on the morning of 30 June, the signal was sent from Mount McKinley designating the following day as Able Day.
and setting in motion the evacuation plan.
All vessels proceeded out of their sectors and quarters for steam through the night, waiting able to eat.
On 1 July 1946, the first atomic bomb of Operation Crossroads burst.
The operations in the McKinney area were concluded on 25 August
The Bureau of Ships group arrived in San Francisco on 7 September, reassembled in Washington, and officers provided by the Bureau of Ships on 23 September to undertake preparation of final reports.
That's page 362.
On page 364, the formation of the electronics group is described in detail.
On their important jobs were the establishment of telemetering of soldiers and measuring the time
pressurization of air blasts, and I won't go into that, except they did have to telemeter a lot of stuff.

The interest of oceanographers is that on page 369, early in February after the oceanography group had requested the use of television for measuring wave heights, the electronics group organized a television project.
The initial project was intended for remote observation of wave formations only, with receiving equipment installed on an aircraft and the image recorded by motion pictures.
When this project was well underway, it became evident that the television cameras also would provide a means of preserving its other remote stations in the general area of the explosion.
Accordingly, another project was set up.
For wave measurement, two television cameras and transmitters were installed on Bikini Island on towers.
The wave height was indicated on two calibrated poles set up in the water in the field of the television cameras.
The television equipment was standard naval design.
It required direct line of sight, so they made this condition possible by installing television receivers on two PBM-5 seaplanes, which also carried automatic recording 35mm cameras.
This way it was possible to obtain a photographic record of the wave heights on the calibrated poles pictured in the field of the television cameras.
They also used sonobuoys and phallometers, two sonobuoys operating on suitable frequencies, were installed in Bikini Lagoon for the use of the oceanography group and its wave measurements.
Twenty-five portable phallometers were provided in the same program, some of them being mounted in the lagoon on buoys, the others on target ships.
Provisions were made for auxiliary power for the phallometers normally carried on target vessels so that these could be used by the oceanography group.
Timing signals were described on page 371.
Navigational radar readings, telemetering of Geiger counters.
There was a drone program.
Test operations.
Instrumentation was a mutual thing, apparently, with all the different organizations of the Bureau of Ships Instrumentation Group.
Option page 378 is a chart of the Oceanography Group 013.
dash B.
Of interest is the head of it, Commander R. LaValle.
The Oceanography Survey Section under Lieutenant Commander C.A.
Barnes.
Wave Measurement Section, Lieutenant Commander F.G. Morris.
Many, many familiar names.
Oceanography Group Formation.

On 13 December 1945, the Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for Special Weapons conferred with representatives of the Manhattan District, the Hydrographic Office, and the Bureau of Ships relative to surface water waves generated by atomic explosions.
In this conference, the oceanographic facilities of the Bureau of Ships and the Hydrographic Office were described for representatives of the Manhattan District.
The group discussed ocean currents as they affected the choice of a safe test site.
and Bureau of Ships Personnel outlined their program of wave studies and instrumentation.

The Oceanography Group is a formal participant in Operation Crossroads with the Bureau of Ships Commander Revell as head, organized into two main sections dealing with oceanographic surveys and wave measurements.
The first of these included four subsections for radiological safety reconnaissance, physical oceanography, biology, and geology.
and fisheries.
The wave measurement section included two subsections dealing with wave motion and seismology.
Specialty design was maintained with other instrumentation groups.
Civilian personnel were drawn from many public and private scientific agencies to assist in planning and carrying out the technical work of the group.
Motionographic survey.

Following the exploratory discussions, the oceanography group began active work not only in the technical problems of wave measurement, but also in the field of physical oceanography, biology, geology, and fisheries.
Every effort was made to ensure that all cognizant government and civilian agencies were represented.
and that no proper interests were neglected.

Based to the investigations in all four fields was the decision to have Ballitz, that's the ship, make a survey of the physical oceanography of Bikini Atoll, for Ballitz eventually became the home for a large number of scientists engaged in a full-fledged scientific expedition, which was an essential preliminary to the tests themselves.
The planning of the Ballitz expedition was a major task involving many different civilian scientific agencies.

A fiscal oceanographic survey was made to establish the current regime and related oceanographic conditions in Bikini Atoll and surrounding waters, which would influence the scattering and diffusion of radioactive substances resulting from the bursts.
Commercial interests in the Pacific were disturbed when the proposed test first appeared in the newspapers over the possibility of far-reaching harmful effects upon the commercial fish supply.
This is on page 381.

Accordingly, on 21 November 1945, the Secretary of the Interior pointed out these dangers to the Secretary of the Navy and rendered the technical advice of the Fisheries and Wildlife Service in the selection of a site where these dangers would be least.

Experiments and observations were made to determine the effects of the bomb burst above and at the surface of the reef and lagoon fishes of Bikini Atoll and on the flood, phlogic, and migratory fishes, particularly tunas,
in the surrounding ocean waters.

The government agencies which supplied personnel and equipment pointed out the opportunity in Operation Crossroads to acquire fundamental scientific knowledge in many fields, including the effects of concussion, wave action, the radiant effects of heat, light, and radioactivity upon aquatic organisms.
They plan to measure... Now turn over the tape to side four.
Turn over this tape to side four and continue.
The discretion of...
